title: Famous Scientists & Discoveries
description: From Newton to Einstein — test your knowledge of the brilliant minds that changed our world!

questions.question: Which scientist is famous for describing the laws of motion and universal gravitation?
questions.explanation: Isaac Newton published his three laws of motion in 1687 in his landmark work 'Principia Mathematica.' Legend says a falling apple inspired his theory of gravity.

questions.question: Albert Einstein is best known for which famous equation?
questions.explanation: Einstein's equation E = mc² shows that energy and mass are interchangeable. He published his theory of special relativity in 1905, his 'miracle year.'

questions.question: Marie Curie was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize. In which field did she win her first?
questions.explanation: Marie Curie won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903 for her work on radioactivity. She later won a second Nobel in Chemistry in 1911, making her the first person to win two.

questions.question: Charles Darwin is best known for his theory of what?
questions.explanation: Darwin published 'On the Origin of Species' in 1859 after years of research, including his famous voyage on HMS Beagle to the Galápagos Islands.

questions.question: Louis Pasteur is credited with developing what process to kill harmful bacteria in beverages?
questions.explanation: Pasteurization, named after Louis Pasteur, involves heating liquids to kill harmful microorganisms. He also created the first vaccines for rabies and anthrax.

questions.question: Galileo Galilei was a pioneer of the telescope. What controversial idea did he champion?
questions.explanation: Galileo supported the heliocentric model — that Earth revolves around the Sun. The Catholic Church put him under house arrest for the last nine years of his life for this belief.

questions.question: Nikola Tesla is best known for his contributions to which type of electrical system?
questions.explanation: Tesla championed alternating current (AC) in the famous 'War of Currents' against Edison's direct current. AC became the standard for power transmission worldwide.

questions.question: Thomas Edison is credited with inventing which of these devices?
questions.explanation: Edison invented the phonograph in 1877, the first device to record and play back sound. He also developed a practical incandescent light bulb and held over 1,000 patents.

questions.question: Stephen Hawking was famous for his work on which cosmic phenomenon?
questions.explanation: Hawking theorized that black holes emit radiation (now called Hawking radiation). Despite living with ALS for over 50 years, he became one of the most celebrated physicists ever.

questions.question: Alexander Fleming accidentally discovered which groundbreaking medicine in 1928?
questions.explanation: Fleming noticed that mold on a petri dish was killing bacteria, leading to the discovery of penicillin — the world's first widely used antibiotic, saving millions of lives.

questions.question: James Watson and Francis Crick are famous for discovering the structure of what?
questions.explanation: Watson and Crick described the double helix structure of DNA in 1953. Their work relied heavily on X-ray crystallography data from Rosalind Franklin's laboratory.

questions.question: Dmitri Mendeleev is credited with creating what important scientific tool?
questions.explanation: Mendeleev published his periodic table in 1869, arranging elements by atomic weight. He even predicted the existence and properties of elements that hadn't been discovered yet.

questions.question: The ancient Greek scientist Archimedes is said to have shouted 'Eureka!' after discovering what principle?
questions.explanation: According to legend, Archimedes discovered the principle of buoyancy while taking a bath and ran through the streets shouting 'Eureka!' meaning 'I have found it!'

questions.question: Rosalind Franklin's X-ray images were crucial to understanding the structure of what molecule?
questions.explanation: Franklin's famous 'Photo 51' X-ray image was key evidence for the double helix structure of DNA. Her contribution was largely unrecognized during her lifetime.

questions.question: Michael Faraday's experiments laid the groundwork for which modern technology?
questions.explanation: Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction in 1831, which is the principle behind electric motors, generators, and transformers that power our modern world.
